line1: The game has just begun. You arrive at Alvari square.
line2: You were told to head for the main-- errmm the bachelor building.

line1: The people at the main building greet you, but stay in.
line2: One of them is thirsty, and asks you nicely to grab a drink for him from Alepa.

line1: You arrive at Alepa only to notice you are out of cash.
line2: Frustrated, you head back to main building. The guy said he'll head for the A-wing.

line1: The thirsty person is hiding from zombies in the bushes.
line2: He advices you to go to the library, but gives no explanation why.

line1: You find spesifically nothing of interest.
line2: The zombies are getting numerous. You forget other objectives and just try to survive.

line1: The grass is covered with goose excrement.
line2: You tread carefully feeling slight disgust.

line1: You come to a dead end.
line2: You have been advised to avoid walking on roads.
You remember your first summer here, eating ice cream on the great stairs.

line1: Some older men are camped here with beer and a battery-operated (poorly functioning) radio.
line2: You overhear one of them say:

line1: Behind Alepa a hippie is going through the trash.
line2: Appearing victorious, he lifts up several loaves of bread and heads home.

line1: Somehow you remember seeing more trees here.
line2: You attribute this to some divine laziness: maybe the god of trees had a bad day.

line1: At a narrow pass the zombies are gathering.
line2: You are almost caught while pondering the amount of zombies.

line1: People in the administrative wing wave at you, as trying to warn you from some danger.q
line2: You have to escape a persistent zombie before you find out what they tried to warn you about.

line1: Student union workers are busy writing on facebook and twitter.
line2: They seem to be doing politics.

line1: You wonder why there are no cars around.
line2: Maybe people have come by foot since it is such a nice day.

line1: The grass is trampled and dying.
line2: For some reason, people (including you) seem to ignore the roads and walk where they please.
You imagine your ancestors building this road. Or at least walking on it. You feel proud.
The Alvari slope is feeling less inclined than normally.

line1: You see a freshman chemist pushing the button for the traffic lights.
line2: All traffic comes to stop and people are frustrated. You scoff at the chemist.
